p: Inclusion complexes formed with a host–guest molecule may exhibit improved chemical or biological properties compared to the host molecule alone. Such inclusion may: (i) improve aqueous solubility, dissolution, and bioavailability [ 24]; (ii) increase the physicochemical stability of drugs and improve the shelf life of drugs [ 3, 24]; (iii) modify the drug delivery site and/or the time profile [ 3, 4, 5]; (iv) reduce or eliminate unpleasant taste and smell [ 3, 4, 5]; (v) prevent drug–drug or drug–excipient interactions [ 4]; and (vi) convert liquid drugs into microcrystalline or amorphous powders [ 13].
